Rationale

The proposed Microfinance Sector Development Program (MSDP)
comprises  two  loans  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)
Special Funds resources (i) a policy loan of $70 million equivalent
to  support  a  reform  program  for  the  microfinance  (MF)  sector,
including social capital enhancement; and (ii) an investment loan of
$80  million  equivalent  to  provide  MF  services  to  the  poor  and
institutional strengthening.

situation  with  (i)  the  rise  in  the  number  of  poor  from  18  million  in

Marginalization of women, vulnerability of the poor, lack of skills for
effective  utilization  of  financial  services,  and  inadequate  basic

Investments  to  enhance  the  supply  of  MF  services,  both  from
private  and  public  sectors,  have  been  minimal  due  to  the

inadequate  retail  capacity  of  MFIs.  To  address  the  issues  of
outreach and sustainability in the context of increasing poverty, the
Government  aims  to  develop  a  pro-poor  financial  system  that  will
have a significant poverty reduction impact.

The  key  objective  of  the  MSDP  is  to  reduce  poverty.  The  MSDP
will develop the MF sector to efficiently provide financial and social
services  to  the  poor.  MF  services,  provided  at  affordable  prices,
will  have  a  significant  poverty  reduction  impact  and  thereby  (i)
increase  incomes  of  poor  households;  (ii)  enhance  outreach,
especially to women; (iii) build social capital; and (iv) reduce risks
faced by the poor. The MSDP will initiate an integrated package of
policy  reforms,  institutional  development,  and  outreach  expansion
to catalyze the growth of the MF sector.

development;  (ii)  establishing  a  Microfinance  Bank  (MFB)  as  a
private-public  enterprise  in  partnership  with  NGOs  to  catalyze
sector  growth;  and  (iii)  putting  in  place  a  legislative,  supervisory,
and regulatory framework to encourage more institutions to provide
MF services.

About  24,750  COs,  comprising  560,000  poor  households,  will  be
developed in a participatory manner through a network of NGOs as
the delivery point for financial services, and provided intensive and
sustained support for capacity building. Nearly 40 percent of these
will  be  women  COs.  The  CO  activists  will  receive  training  on
community  mobilization  and  management;  capacity  enhancement
of  the  poor;  and  leadership  skills.  In  addition,  about  4,500
subprojects for small-scale community-based infrastructure will be
financed. MSDF and CIF will fund these investments.

Membership in COs will facilitate access to MF and social services
leading to greater social and economic empowerment of the poor.
These opportunities are especially significant for women who have
had  little  opportunity  to  interact  with  institutions  external  to  their
community.  The  involvement  of  COs  in  identifying,  planning,
executing,  and  monitoring  physical  infrastructure  projects  will
enhance  access  of  poor  communities  to  infrastructure  to  improve
their  livelihoods  through  efficient  and  productive  use  of  local
resources.  Through  their  participation  in  MF  service  delivery,
NGOs will become more effective in working with communities; this
will  lead  to  opportunities  for  expansion  and  greater  impact  on
poverty  reduction.  MFB  will  ensure  that  borrowers  are  aware  of
environmental  issues,  and  that  these  are  satisfactorily  taken  into
account in the use of loan funds.

By addressing multiple dimensions of poverty, the MSDP will have
a significant and sustainable poverty reduction impact, during and
beyond  the  MSDP  duration.  The  development  of  a  conducive
policy  and  legal  framework  will  catalyze  private  investments  and
private-public  synergies  for  augmenting  the  retail  capacity  for
outreach.  The  promotion  of  a  lead  institution  such  as  MFB  will

INTRODUCTION

The number of poor people in Pakistan more than doubled during the 1990s. Nearly 33

Appraisal Mission5 visited Pakistan during 7-25 August 2000 to enhance the scope of the MSDP
and firm up the implementation arrangements. The Government’s development policy letter and

Macroeconomic Context

III.

THE SECTOR

5.
Pakistan’s  economy  in  the  1990s  has  been  marked  by  declining  growth  rates,  fiscal
imbalances,  deterioration  of  physical  infrastructure,  inadequate  social  safety  nets,  and
institutional weaknesses resulting from poor governance. The persistence of these factors has
worsened the poverty situation. Economic sanctions compounded long-standing socioeconomic
difficulties.  Erosion  of  investor  confidence  in  the  latter  part  of  1998,  the  virtual  cessation  of
private  capital  flows,  and  the  suspension  of  new  official  development  assistance  affected
economic growth. The trade deficit grew sharply, foreign exchange reserves were less than two
months of imports, and total foreign debt stood at $30 billion at the end of June 1999.

The  structural  reforms  undertaken  by  the  Government  have  resulted  in  real  gross
6.
domestic product (GDP) growth of 4.5 percent during FY2000 as against 3.2 percent in FY1999.
The Government has indicated its willingness to speed up the pace of structural reforms to meet
the  major  challenges  of  (i)  reducing  poverty,  (ii)  improving  governance  and  administration,  (iii)
improving  the  fiscal  and  balance  of  payments  positions,  (iv)  restoring  investor  confidence,  (v)
achieving  higher  growth  on  a  sustainable  basis,  and  (vi)  improving  social  indicators.  To  assist
the  Government’s  reform  efforts  and  to  provide  balance  of  payments  support,  a  stand-by
arrangement amounting to $1.5 billion is expected to be approved by the International Monetary
Fund  in  November  2000.  Discussions  are  ongoing  for  a  comprehensive  multiyear  package

B.

Sector Description and Recent Performance

1.

Overview

The  institutional  structure  of  the  financial  system  in  Pakistan  is  elaborate.  The  State
7.
Bank  of  Pakistan  (SBP),  the  central  bank,  manages  and  executes  monetary,  credit,  interest
rate,  and  foreign  exchange  policies,  and  is  the  sole  prudential  regulator  for  all  deposit-taking
institutions.  SBP  oversees  21  domestic  scheduled  commercial  banks  (CBs)  of  which  4  are
state-owned, 21 foreign banks, 4 specialized banks, 11 development finance institutions (DFIs),
16  investment  banks,  3  discount  and  guarantee  houses,  4  housing  finance  companies,  and  2
joint  venture  companies.  State-owned  CBs  hold  almost  60  percent  of  the  total  assets  of  the
financial  institutions  and  have  primarily  financed  working  capital.  The  DFIs  hold  about  11
percent of the total assets and have provided term finance to industry, and both term and short-
term  finance  for  agriculture.  Other  financial  institutions  such  as  leasing  companies  and
investment banks together account for barely 5 percent of the banking system’s assets. Among
the  financial  institutions,  6  CBs  and  2  DFIs  have  a  limited  MF  portfolio.  The  MF  market  is
essentially served by NGOs, and informal arrangements by agricultural traders, input suppliers,
moneylenders, and landlords, especially in rural areas.

 3

Institutional  MF7  is  a  recent  development  in  Pakistan  and,  therefore,  has  a  very  limited
8.
outreach.  However,  the  poverty  reduction  potential  of  MF  is  widely  recognized  at  the  policy-
making  level  and  among  the  development  community.  In  the  economic  and  social  context  of
Pakistan,  MF  is  understood  to  comprise  financial  services,  particularly  savings  and  credit,  for
the  poor  with  a  significant  degree  of  social  intermediation.  This  involves  improving  the  social
condition  of  the  poor  who  have  been  largely  excluded  from  access  to  financial  and  social
services,  and  includes  community  mobilization,  skills  development,  risk  mitigation,  and  access
to  basic  infrastructure.  Initial  savings  up  to  PRs2,000  ($35)  and  a  first  time  loan  of  about
PRs16,540 ($295)8 are generally considered as MF.

9.
Policies  and  guidelines  governing  the  financial  system  and  the  framework  of  the
Government’s poverty reduction strategy influence the MF sector. The environment for MF has
improved with the recognition that MF is critical to poverty reduction and NGOs can be effective
development partners to enhance the quality of service through participatory community-based
approaches. NGOs can attain legal status, and are eligible to receive resources from aid-funded
projects, Government-funded projects, and from projects where the Government has borrowed
from funding agencies.

2.

Clients and Client Characteristics

As of June 1999, Pakistan’s population was estimated at 134.5 million. Two thirds of the
10.
population live in rural areas. The number of poor is estimated at 45 million (33 percent of the
population)  in  6.3  million  households.9  Of  the  poor,  33  million,  representing  4.7  million
households  live  in  rural  areas.  All  poor  households  are  potential  clients  for  both  financial  and
nonfinancial  social  services.  Government  considers  half  the  adult  poor  population  (nearly  10
million) as potential MF clients. Among this client base, women bear a disproportionately high
share of the burden of poverty due to (i) low social status, (ii) lesser endowments of land and
productive  assets,  (iii)  limited  access  to  economic  opportunities  and  social  services,  and  (iv)
restricted  mobility.  Women  are  poorer,  less  healthy,  and  less  educated  than  men.  These
differences are more pronounced in rural areas (Appendix 4). Even though economically active,
the contribution of women is inadequately documented, understood, and appreciated.

In  urban  areas,  the  poor  include  vendors,  small  traders,  and  laborers  in  the  service,
11.

landowners,  sharecropper-tenants,  rural  artisans,  and  landless  laborers.  Sharecropper-tenants
are  among  the  poorest.  Bonded  labor  is  common  among  this  group.  Artisans,  the  traditional
service  providers  to  the  rural  community  (e.g.,  blacksmiths,  carpenters,  weavers,  barbers,
tailors) are mostly poor. Landless laborers are among the poorest of the poor.

work), (iv) employment outside the  community, and (v) migration to urban areas (estimated at

3.

Microfinance and the Poor

a. 

Demand

The  average  size  of  loan  taken  by  poor  households  from  NGOs  is  about  PRs16,540
14.
($295)  at  an  interest  rate  of  18-20  percent  per  annum.  Considering  these,  the  estimated
potential demand for microcredit is about $2 billion10 based on the number of poor households
(6.3 million) or about $3 billion based on half the adult poor population (10 million). Similarly, the
estimates of deposit possibilities range from $225 million to $350 million per annum. Based on
population distribution, two thirds of this demand is considered to emanate from the rural poor.
In MF projects implemented by NGOs in Pakistan, the depositors outnumber borrowers by 2-4
times. The poor emphasize the safety and accessibility of savings facilities as many have lost
their savings in the past due to failures of cooperatives and finance companies.

15.
Most  of  the  demand  for  MF  in  rural  areas  is  for  agriculture  production  (50  percent),
livestock (25 percent), and the balance for other household-based income-generating activities
(IGAs). In urban areas, most of the demand is for small business and self-employed ventures.
Households are extended families and the pool of labor within a family unit creates the potential
for  a  diverse  range  of  income-earning  opportunities.  Demand  attributes  include  (i)  small  and
frequent loans; (ii) terms compatible with the nature of activity; (iii) preference of women, due to
restricted  mobility,  for  simple  and  speedy  delivery  mechanisms  placed  within  the  community;
and (iv) significant and sustained social preparation to familiarize the poor with managing IGAs.
Interest rate sensitivity is high in rural areas due to the general low level of economic activity.
The  apprehension  of  becoming  indebted,  particularly  among  women,  due  to  failed  enterprises
(e.g., death of livestock, failure of business, crop failures) is widespread.

4. 

Financial Sector Reforms and Microfinance

17.
The  Government  considers  an  efficient  financial  system  necessary  for  macroeconomic
stability.  Therefore,  the  banking  system  is  being  strengthened12  by  (i)  fundamentally  changing
norms for governance; (ii) restructuring to conserve assets, downsizing staff and branches, and
reducing bad debts; (iii) implementing debt recovery measures; (iv) strengthening the prudential
and supervisory framework; (v) improving legal and judicial enforcement of banking courts; and
(vi) privatizing all but one state-owned CB. SBP has been empowered in all matters concerning
monetary  and  banking  policies,  as  well  as  for  governance  and  management  of  the  financial
institutions.  These  reforms  are  to  be  extended  to  the  DFIs.  The  Government  plans  to
restructure, recapitalize, downsize, and privatize the DFIs. Interest rates were deregulated and
loans up to PRs100,000 ($1,785) are not required to be collateralized. In general, the reforms
constitute  a  positive  financial  environment.  Restoring  SBP’s  authority  in  banking  supervision
and greater transparency requirements have significantly strengthened good governance.

Complementing these reforms, the ADB-funded Capital Market Development Program13
18.
aims  to  accelerate  the  mobilization  of  long-term  resources  and  improve  the  efficiency  of  its
allocation through a diversified and competitive capital market. The major developments include
(i)  establishment  of  a  central  depository  system,  (ii)  automation  of  stock  exchanges,  and  (iii)
establishment  of  credit  rating  agencies.  New  laws  have  been  promulgated  to  prohibit  insider
trading,  regulate  stock  exchange  members,  and  offer  stock  options  to  employees.  The
Securities  and  Exchange  Commission  of  Pakistan  is  being  strengthened.  Reform  agenda
includes establishing a national clearing and settlement system, broadening the capital market
base by linking smaller cities, and developing internet-based trading.

The banking reforms have not been extended to cover the specific needs of MF, which
19.
include (i) a conducive policy to encourage emergence of MFIs as depository institutions;14 (ii)
corresponding creation of a supervisory and regulatory system for orderly sector development;
(iii)  flexibility  to  adopt  practices  and  procedures  for  banking  with  the  poor,  such  as  mobile
banking and group collateral; (iv) free limit to accumulate a noncollateralized loan portfolio; and
(v)  insulation  from  political  interference.  The  MF  sector  can  seamlessly  integrate  with  the
broader financial sector if these are addressed.

C.

Constraints and Issues

30. With an outreach of less than 5 percent of poor households, affordable MF services are
not available to the majority of the poor; thus they are unable to participate in the local economy.
The outreach of the NGOs is expected to grow to 400,000 households (currently about 60,000)
by the end of 2004.20 Therefore, in the absence of complementary or alternative arrangements,
the  MF  market  will  remain  grossly  underserved,  and  its  poverty  reduction  potential  largely
unrealized in the medium to long term. For this potential to be realized, the following constraints
and issues must be addressed.

1.

Social

a.

Inadequate Access of the Poor to Services

31.
Inadequate  access  to  productive  resources  and  social  services  has  resulted  in  low
indicators of well-being and lack of employment opportunities. This situation is compounded in
rural  areas  where  access  is  even  more  difficult  due  to  inadequate  or  complete  lack  of  basic
infrastructure. Low skill level and absence of support for human resource development for the
poor  prevents  them  from  diversifying  their  household  income.  Government  interventions  have
not  yielded  the  desired  impact  due  to  inadequate  emphasis  on  community-based  participatory
approaches.  Resource  availability  relative  to  the  requirements  for  the  social  sectors  is  low.
Much  of  the  investment  required  is  for  public  services  where  private  sector  investments  are
unlikely. Without these services, MF will have less than the intended impact.

b.

Obstacles for Microfinance Outreach to Women

32.
Social intermediation costs to enhance women’s access to MF are significantly higher in
Pakistan  as  constraints  on  mobility,  social  interaction,  and  skills  development  must  be
addressed on a sustained basis. Although returns from social intermediation in terms of social
capital  and  demonstrative  effects  are  high,  investments  are  limited  due  to  high  cost.
Consequently,  the  gender  orientation  of  organizations,  products,  and  delivery  mechanisms  is
insufficient  to  enhance  outreach  to  women.  Inadequate  social  preparation  adversely  affects
group cohesion, the quality of loan portfolio, and ultimately the sustainability of MF operations.

c.

33.

unfair  terms  of  participation  in  the  local  economy,  and  vulnerability  to  economic  and  physical
downturns.  Poor  households  forego  potentially  viable  technologies,  production  choices,  and

Financial

a.

Microfinance-Specific Policy Framework

In  the  early  stages  of  MF  sector  development,  a  conducive  policy  environment  is
34.
required to encourage innovations and to allow a diverse set of institutions to provide a range of
services,  particularly  savings,  in  a  supervised  and  regulated  environment.  The  required  policy
attributes  include  (i)  promotion  of  institutions  that  can  target  the  poor  with  adequate  gender
emphasis, (ii) acceptance of individuals as well as groups of individuals for MF transactions, (iii)
mechanisms to ensure that social intermediation precedes and accompanies MF services, (iv)
significant  investments  in  social  intermediation,  (v)  pro-poor  financial  innovations  such  as
measures  to  mitigate  risks  faced  by  the  poor,  (vi)  realizing  public-private  sector  synergy,  (vii)
autonomy  in  pricing  and  client  selection,  (viii)  measures  to  integrate  MF  with  the  financial
system (para.19), and (ix) proactive role of SBP in developing the MF sector.

b.

Institutional Limitations

35.
The  financial  reforms  have  put  in  place  a  policy  framework  for  efficient  financial
intermediation that enables institutions to concentrate on their core competencies. For the CBs
and DFIs, this core competency is serving the upper and middle segments of the market. While
the banking system has responded positively to the reform initiatives, an efficient and financially
sound  system,  barring  select  institutions,  has  yet  to  emerge.  The  high  level  of  nonperforming
loans  attributed  to  slack  industrial  activity  is  widespread.  Some  institutions  have  capital
adequacy  below  the  prescribed  8  percent  of  risk-weighted  assets.  Competitive  pressures  for
product differentiation and cost reduction is increasing. Smaller institutions are not able to invest
in new technology and a branch network to access low cost retail deposits to gain competitive
advantage. The banking system is becoming concentrated in a few large institutions.

MF  is  unlikely  to  become  a  significant  part  of  CBs’  portfolios.  Operating  procedures  of
36.

c.

Islamic Banking

40.
Islamic  banking  is  practiced  in  Pakistan  for  transactions  between  banks  and  clients,
including MF services. Markup over the principal and service charge are applied, as interest is
prohibited  under  Sharia  (Islamic  Law).  The  revenue  under  this  mode  has  been  higher  for
lenders  compared  with  the  interest-based  system.  Recently,  the  Supreme  Court  of  Pakistan
ruled  that  markup  and  service  charges  are  applicable  only  when  actual  commodity  or  assets
change  hands  and  the  supplier  is  the  financier.  A  Commission  on  Transformation  of  the
Financial System has been set up to prepare operating guidelines. This may require systemic
changes affecting all financial institutions and will require adjustments to operating procedures.
In the meantime, MF services consistent with Islamic banking norms are already being provided
and related training programs conducted.

3.

Services

41.
Delivery of financial services to the poor, particularly in rural areas is constrained by low
population density in some provinces, inadequate communication services, small loans, and low
household  savings  that  increase  transaction  costs.  Seasonality  of  the  agriculture  business
cycle,  the  main  occupation  for  poor  households,  and  the  high  probability  of  risks  add  to  the
problems  of  providing  MF  services  to  the  rural  poor.  In  addition,  while  security  of  savings  is  a
prime  concern  for  rural  households,  secure  savings  facilities  are  not  accessible.  CBs  find  it
costly  to  cater  to  small  depositors.  Savings  through  NGO  intermediaries,  deposited  with  CBs,
are generally compulsory and do not necessarily provide the maximum return to the depositor.
NGOs cannot deploy such savings as microcredit.

IV.

THE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM

A. 

Rationale

58. While  many  factors  contribute  to  poverty,  its  most  obvious  manifestation  is  insufficient
household income. Poor households are permanently in deficit or in debt. Evidence from many
countries has shown that access to and efficient provision of savings and credit facilities, along
with social intermediation, enables the poor to stabilize their income and consumption, manage
risks  better,  gradually  build  assets,  develop  microenterprises,  enhance  income-earning
capacity, and thus enjoy a relatively better quality of life.

59.
Currently  served  by  informal  arrangements  and  a  few  small  NGO  initiatives,  the  MF
sector in Pakistan is unable to expand. MF services are provided on a very limited scale, and
savings at positive real interest rates for the poor are practically excluded. By borrowing at high
interest rates in informal markets the poor are trapped in low-risk, low-return investments, which
in the long run, will widen income gaps. Due to lack of access to alternative affordable sources
the poor are unable to increase or diversify their household income. Together these have long-
term negative effects on consumption and asset buildup of the poor households.

60.
Institutions to bridge demand and supply gap for MF services do not yet exist in Pakistan
owing  to  policy  and  legal  gaps  and  the  lack  of  a  supportive  financial  infrastructure  (paras.  19
and 34). CBs, in general, are neither structured nor geared to extend their MF exposure beyond
experimental forays. CBs’ restructuring priorities are downsizing and recovery of doubtful debts,
which constitute a significant part of their loan portfolio. Most DFIs have numerous financial and
organizational  issues.  Politicization  has  eroded  autonomy  and  good  governance,  and  the
persistent poor loan repayment record has eroded the DFIs’ fund base. CBs and DFIs primarily
cater  to  the  upper  and  middle  segments  of  the  financial  markets,  rural  elite,  and  farmers  with
sizeable landholdings, rather than to the assetless poor.

61.
Social  constraints  to  enhancing  outreach  include  (i)  social  barriers  affecting  women’s
access to MF, (ii) vulnerability of the poor to economic and physical downturns, and (iii) weak
social preparedness for effective utilization of financial services. These are further exacerbated
by  institutions  of  governance  that  tend  to  exclude  the  poor,  especially  women,  from  the  entire
decision  making  process.  These  have  impeded  the  growth  of  the  MF  sector  resulting  in  a
majority of the poor without access to affordable MF. The small number of poor households with
access  to  institutional  MF  are  not  assured  of  permanent  access  because  of  the  limited  retail
capacity and inadequate resource base of MF service providers.

62.
To  realize  the  poverty  reduction  potential  of  MF,  substantial  continuing  resources  are
required  to  meet  the  magnitude  of  demand.  Efficient  institutional  and  market  mechanisms  are
needed  whereby  funds  can  be  sourced  in  the  domestic  market  and  supplemented  by  funding
agencies.  Funds  need  to  be  allocated  efficiently  through  appropriately  designed  and  priced
services  to  the  poor  for  investment  in  agriculture  and  microenterprises  in  a  profitable  manner.
To accomplish this, an integrated package of policy, institutional development, capacity building,
and outreach expansion is needed, along with strong commitment to pursue reforms. The sector
development  program  modality  has  thus  been  chosen  for  facilitating  the  adoption  of  basic
sectoral  reforms  to  ensure  that  an  adequate  policy  and  institutional  framework  is  in  place  to
optimize investment lending. The MSDP includes a policy loan to support policy reforms and an
investment loan to support sector investment to enhance outreach. By formalizing the linkages
between policy and investment components the MSDP will yield considerable benefits in terms
of fostering a long-term sector wide perspective for sustained poverty reduction efforts.

Facilitate Establishment of Microfinance Bank

70.
MFB  was  designed  to  implement  the  MF  policy  in  response  to  the  rising  incidence  of

The objective of MFB (Appendix 7) is to provide sustainable MF services to the poor in

72. While  observing  successful  MF  practices  (paras.  53-54),  MFB  will  provide  affordable

Establish Mechanisms for Enhancing Social Capital

76.
As part of the MSDP, the Microfinance Social Development Fund (MSDF) (Appendix 8)
was established in SBP for intensive and sustained support for promotion of COs and capacity
building for the poor, especially women, to effectively utilize MF services. The revenue earned
from MSDF will meet defined social preparation costs associated with community mobilization,
skills development, social awareness, basic numeracy skills, and selection and management of

empowerment  through  training  in  community  management,  capacity  enhancement  for  specific

its net profit in terms of MFB Rules 2000 issued by SBP.

77.
To  leverage  the  social  mobilization  through  MSDF,  the  Community  Investment  Fund
(CIF) (Appendix 9) was established in SBP, with a term of 25 years, to increase the access of

and monitoring community-based infrastructure subprojects will empower them and serve as an
incentive  to  mobilize  and  strengthen  COs.  This  will  help  expand  the  MF  market  and  maintain
peer pressure as a substitute for physical collateral. The minimum outlay of CIF is $20 million

5.

Pilot Risk Mitigation Mechanisms for the Poor as a Safety Net Measure

79.
As a safety net measure, the Risk Mitigation Fund (RMF) was established (Appendix 10)
in  SBP  with  initial  MFB  contribution.  RMF’s  objective  is  to  reduce  risks  associated  with  failed
IGAs, both farm and non-farm, of MFB clients. RMF will assist MFB borrowers, not MFB per se,
in case of loss of IGAs (acquired through MFB loan) due to unforeseen circumstances beyond
their control. RMF is expected to mitigate risks faced by about 27,000 poor during the MSDP.
Assistance from RMF will be provided using a community-based participatory process where 75
percent  of  the  CO  members  will  approve  assistance  from  RMF  to  any  individual.  Experience
with  community-based  risk  mitigation  mechanism  gained  by  RMF  will  provide  the  basis  for
assessing the feasibility of actuarial-based insurance services for the poor.

80.
Although small in absolute amount, the value of the savings of the poor relative to their
income  is  considerable  and  therefore  needs  to  be  protected.  MFB  will  be  a  deposit-taking
institution, both from its (poor) borrowers and also from nonborrowers. Given substantial paid-up
capital  and  viable  operations,  no  immediate  deposit  guarantee  is  considered  necessary.
However, as a matter of precaution, the Deposit Protection Fund (DPF) was established in SBP
to partially secure the savings mobilized by MFB (Appendix 11).33 This will provide assurance to
the poor of the safety of their savings. At the end of year 6 the DPF balance is expected to be
about 50 percent of MFB deposits. SBP, in consultation with ADB, will explore the possibility of
converting DPF into an actuarial-based system.

81.
MFB will contribute a part of its net profit to RMF and DPF. In addition, the Government
will  contribute  the  difference  between  the  borrowing  rate  and  the  relending  rate  to  RMF  and
DPF on a recurring basis. An initial contribution of $5 million is expected from the Government
for both RMF and DPF.

93.
The formation and strengthening of COs will be contracted to NGOs (principally NRSP in

CO members; (iv) a group decision to form a CO, appoint the president, and a CO activist; and

usually at two-week intervals, during which CO members deposit savings in a CO account; (vii)
preparation, by each member who wishes to borrow, of an investment plan, and agreement to
the loan size by at least 80 percent of members; (viii) appraisal and eventual loan decision by
the field officer of MFB; (ix) signing of the loan agreement by each borrower, witnessed by the
CO president; and (x) disbursement of loan proceeds to borrowers.

a  cash  buffer  for  small  emergencies.  Through  their  participation,  NGOs  will  become  more

104. Use of low cost funds from ADB’s Special Fund resources is justified in support of policy

organizations. Private sector investment has been brought in MF while ensuring support for social
sectors where continued and direct Government involvement is warranted. Socially, the policy has

opportunities  to  the  poor  to  increase  household  income.  For  the  first  time,  the  poor  will  have
access  to  safe,  liquid  and,  remunerative  savings  facilities.  The  policy  actions  are  within  the

Risks and Safeguards

1.

Policy Loan

The  MSDP  design  is  based  on  lessons  learned  from  successful  practices,  and  has

138.
strong ownership by the Government and stakeholders. The following are identified risks.

139. Delay  in  policy  reforms.  Effective  policy  dialogue,  stakeholder  coordination,  and
capacity  building  support  are  safeguards.  The  Government  has  demonstrated  strong
commitment to the reforms, and has already taken several measures as agreed with ADB. The
Government’s  commitment  to  ensure  efficient  resource  allocation  through  the  banking  system
and its experience with banking reforms will ensure that DFI restructuring starts in earnest.

140.
Lack  of  autonomy.  Despite  measures  to  ensure  autonomy,  private-public  partnership,
and professional management, MFB may come under political pressure to disburse credit faster
than  its  capacity  allows.  MFB  ordinance  clearly  establishes  (i)  autonomy  of  the  board  of
directors, (ii) no government official or member of political party is eligible to become a director,
and  (iii)  SBP  will  be  the  supervisory  and  regulatory  authority.  Operations  in  partnership  with
NGOs  will  ensure  that  social  mobilization  dictates  the  pace  of  service  delivery.  Furthermore,
rules issued under the MFB statute will strengthen good corporate governance.

2.

Investment Loan

141. No  growth  in  income  of  poor.  Income  of  the  poor  may  not  increase  due  to  slow
macroeconomic growth and constrained market opportunities. Improved economic performance
and pro-poor growth are expected as a result of IPRSP implementation. The Government has
also  speeded  up  the  macroeconomic  reforms.  In  addition,  as  part  of  the  social  intermediation
process, clients will be advised on prudent economic choices.

142. Marginalization of poor and women. Access of women to MF may remain below the
targeted 40 percent due to the slow pace of formation of COs, capacity building, and expansion
of MFB branch network. Procedures to mainstream women’s participation are an essential part
of  the  MSDP  design.  The  MSDP  aims  to  address  both  economic  and  social  integration  as
follows: (i) MSDF and CIF will ensure adequate investments are made in social intermediation
to enhance the absorptive capacity of the poor; (ii) 40 percent of the field staff of MFB will be
women;  (iii)  mobility  constraints  will  be  addressed  through  vehicles;  (iv)  resource  support  for
expansion  of  MFB  will  ensure  that  it  establishes  its  presence  in  remote  areas  as  early  as
possible;  and  (v)  collection  and  analysis  of  gender  desegregated  data  will  enable  continuous
monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the  impact  of  the  MSDP  on  women  and  ensure  adjustments  as
required. In addition, effective targeting of poor communities, participatory processes, screening
of subprojects, small loan size, and pricing at above the CB-based lending rates will make MFB
loans less attractive to nonpoor.

143. High delinquency. MFB is most vulnerable to increases in loan losses and reductions in
loan  revenues.  The  following  constitute  an  effective  safeguard  against  delinquency:  (i)
significant  investment  in  capacity  building  of  MFB,  (ii)  adoption  of  successful  practices,  (iii)
adequate  loan  loss  provisions,  (iv)  risk  mitigation  measures  to  help  borrowers  stabilize  their
income  flows,  (v)  adequate  training  and  capacity  building  of  clients,  and  (vi)  peer  pressure  to
ensure  repayments.  In  addition  MFB  will  have  a  sufficient  capital  base  to  bear  financial  risks,
assured  support  for  social  intermediation  to  help  the  poor  to  effectively  use  financial  services,
expertise of the private sector, and partnership arrangements with NGOs.

The purpose of the Microfinance Sector Development Program (MSDP) is to develop the microfinance (MF) sector to efficiently provide a range of financial and social
services to the poor, especially women who disproportionately bear the burden of poverty. Services provided at affordable prices will have a significant poverty
reduction impact and thereby (i) increase incomes of poor households; (ii) enhance outreach, especially to women; (iii) build social capital; and (iv) reduce the risks
faced by the poor.

To achieve this, the Government of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan will initiate policy actions for the development of the MF sector. These include (i) developing an
enabling policy framework for MF development; (ii) facilitating the establishment of a Microfinance Bank (MFB); (iii) developing an enabling framework that incorporates
legislative, supervisory, and regulatory aspects to facilitate and encourage the emergence of microfinance institutions (MFIs); (iv) establishing mechanisms to enhance
social capital; (v) piloting risk mitigation mechanisms for the poor as a safety net measure; and (vi) initiating measures to restructure development finance institutions
(DFIs).

B. Facilitate Establishment of Microfinance Bank

Facilitate the
establishment of
MFB to provide
affordable and
sustainable services
to the poor.

Less than 5 percent of the
poor households have access
to affordable MF services that
could enable them to increase
and diversify household
income. In this early stage of
the MF sector in Pakistan,
more institutions are required
to bridge the demand and
supply gap for MF. The
restructured commercial banks
and DFIs will primarily target
the upper and middle segment
of the market. Retail capacity
for delivery of MF therefore
needs to be augmented
immediately to provide access
to affordable services for
poverty reduction.

The Government has promulgated an ordinance for
the establishment of MFB incorporating the core
attributes of the MF policy statement to facilitate
banking with the poor. The statute provides for (i)
autonomy to develop, market, and service products
on a sustainable basis; (ii) exclusive focus on the
poor; (iii) gender emphasis; (iv) operational flexibility
to provide services through and/or in partnership
with NGOs; (v) broad-based equity participation
reflecting private-public ownership; (vi) a
professional board of directors with representation of
women; (vii) delegation of rules and regulation-
making power to board of directors; (viii) eligibility to
raise resources from the financial market; and (ix)
SBP as the regulatory and supervisory authority.

To operationalize MFB: (i) equity investments have
been made by private and public entities, (ii)
investors have nominated a professional private
sector-led board of directors with three NGO
representatives, including two women, (iii) the board
of directors have established rules based on the
recognized principles of good corporate governance
and this has been approved by SBP, (iv) SBP has
formulated a supervisory and regulatory framework
for MFB, and (v) MFB has commenced operations in
partnership with NGOs.

E.  Pilot Risk Mitigation Mechanisms for the Poor as a Safety Net Measure

Implement safety-
net measures to
mitigate risks and
reduce vulnerability.

A Risk Mitigation Fund (RMF) has been created to
assist MFB clients in case of loss of income
generating asset due to unforeseen circumstances
beyond their control. A Deposit Protection Fund
(DPF) has been created to provide partial guarantee
to MFB depositors.

Operations of RMF and
DPF are reviewed and
audited by independent
auditors. The outcome will
be submitted to ADB
annually for review.

SBP, MFB, and ADB
will explore the
possibility of converting
the RMF and DPF into
actuarial-based
systems.

MFB has made initial contribution to MSDF and CIF.
The Government is committed to contribute funds
equivalent to $40 million and $20 million,
respectively to MSDF and CIF. MFB is mandated to
set aside 10 percent of its surplus for social
intermediation purposes.

Money will accrue in RMF and DPF from the
difference between the rate at which the ADB credit
line for subborrower investments under the MSDP
($68 million equivalent) will be made available to the
Government and the relending rate from the
Government to MFB. The relending rate will be
based on the average weighted cost of deposits in
the banking industry.

MFB is required to contribute up to 5 percent of its
net profit to RMF and DPF. The Government is
committed to contribute funds equivalent to $5
million each in RMF and DPF.

SOCIAL DIMENSIONS OF POVERTY

1.
Pakistan has 134 million citizens; 33 percent live in urban areas and 67 percent in rural
areas.  About 44 million or 33 percent of the population live in poverty. Three fourths of the poor
live  in  rural  area.  The  average  family  size  is  seven  people.  The  level  of  poverty  is  nearly  45
percent1  when  it  is  recognized  as  a  multidimensional  phenomenon  including  affordability  of
education,  health  care,  clean  water;  plus  opportunities  for  good  jobs,  security,  political,  and
social  freedom.  Households  headed  by  women,  those  with  many  dependents,  those  in  rural
areas  with  no  livestock,  and  single  earner  households  in  urban  areas  are  among  the  poorest.
Pakistan  ranks  138th  among  174  countries  in  the  terms  of  the  human  development  index  of
United Nations Development Programme.

Urbanization was very rapid after the creation of Pakistan in 1947. Seasonal migration is
2.
common  and  migrants  retain  strong  ties  to  their  family  homes  in  the  countryside.  Industrial
growth, led by a small group of large-scale private manufacturers with close ties to banks and
government who promoted mechanization, attracted many laborers to the growing cities. Capital
has accumulated in a few large urban centers. Urban society remains stratified with a small elite
and masses, similar to that traditionally found in the countryside.

3.
In  rural  areas,  people  live  in  villages  of  50  to  3,000  households.  They  are  landlords,
tenant farmers, artisans, or landless laborers.  Landlords, classified by the size of their holdings,
are  the  social  and  economic  elite.  Sharecroppers  contribute  only  labor  and  keep  25  to  33
percent of the crops. Sharecropper-tenants share the cost of production, contribute labor, and
receive 50 percent of the output. Both are generally poor. Those who lease land (25 percent of
tenants)  may  be  better-off,  provided  that  rent  is  not  excessive.  Artisans  provide  traditional
services  to  communities  and  are  frequently  poor.  Landless  laborers  are  the  poorest,  and  by
virtue  of  being  in  debt  to  landowners  may  be  obliged  to  labor  on  their  lands—as  bonded
laborers—to try to pay their ever-increasing debts.

4.
The  family  system  is  the  basis  of  rural  life.  It  defines  individual  identity,  social  status,
political role, and economic level often including occupational category. It is defined by men, so
family  membership  is  inherited  through  men,  and  women  move  from  their  natal  family  to  their
“real”  family  upon  marriage,  often  in  their  early  teens.  Women  live  as  much  as  possible  in
purdah, and have limited social and economic interaction. Early in life, they internalize attitudes
that  contribute  to  perpetuation  of  this  system  and  generally  accept  this  as  culturally  and
religiously  appropriate.  For  many,  the  notion  that  they  might  exercise  public  choice  is  remote,
even though they may attain considerable influence within the family, especially later in life.

5.
Women’s lives focus primarily on the domestic realm where they work long hours every
day  to  care  for  the  men,  children,  elderly,  and  sick,  and  do  the  cooking,  cleaning,  washing,
mending,  water  carrying,  and  so  on.  Rural  women  also  make  significant  contributions  to
agricultural  work  (planting,  weeding,  watering,  harvesting,  and  preserving)  and/or  earn  small
amounts of money through livestock raising, selling eggs or milk, embroidery, and other crafts
that  can  be  worked  on  as  time  is  available.  These  are  rendered  more  difficult  in  absence  of
basic  infrastructure  such  as  drinking  water,  sanitation,  rural  roads,  and  irrigation.  Their
economic  contributions  are  misunderstood  and  underreported.  Women  in  urban  centers  have
better  access  to  services  and  may  become  teachers  or  doctors,  but  opportunities  to  work
depend upon the opinions of their parents-in-law. Nuclear households are increasingly common

in cities as well-to-do women seek to establish their own homes where they can exercise some
authority earlier in life.

6.
Women  are  poorer,  less  healthy,  and  less  educated  than  men.  The  60-year  life
expectancy  of  women  is  the  same  as  men,  making  Pakistan  one  of  the  very  few  countries
where women do not outlive men. Only about half of the rural population have access to clean
water  and  only  20  percent  have  access  to  proper  sanitation  facilities.  Literacy  and  school
enrollment  rates  for  girls  and  women,  especially  in  rural  areas,  are  significantly  lower  than  for
men and compare unfavorably with most of the world. In many rural areas less than 10 percent
of  women  are  literate.  Women  suffer  chronic  malnutrition  and  anemia  because  of  frequent
childbearing.

Over  80  percent  of  farmers  have  less  than  5.0  hectares  of  land,  thus,  demand  for
7.
seasonal  labor  is  minimal.  Deforestation  of  upland  areas  has  caused  soil  erosion,  which  has
contributed  to  clogged  reservoirs  and  irrigation  systems,  and  increased  risk  of  flooding,
waterlogging, and soil salinity. Work traditionally done by some artisans is increasingly replaced
by  new  technologies  as  well.  Most  rural  families  have  added  secondary  occupations  or
branched out from traditional roles into related work. Rural-urban migration has been continuous
from the 1960s onward and is now about 1.3 percent per year.

The  poor  seek  opportunities  in  animal  husbandry,  small-scale  manufacturing,  food
8.
processing, and labor and services for cash. Information about distant markets and new forms
of activity is scarce, and the risk entailed in starting little known enterprises is simply too high for
those with few assets and many dependents. Difficulty in obtaining credit further restricts their
options.  Both  resources  and  facilities  to  acquire  skills  to  diversify  into  new  activities  are
inadequate. No effective risk mitigation mechanism is accessible to the poor. Illiteracy adds to
their disadvantages.

The  poor  need  cash  for  consumption  as  well  as  for  investment.  Events  like  illness,
9.
especially of a working man, provision of dowry for marriage of a daughter, damage to homes or
lands  from  monsoon  rains,  food  shortages,  and  funeral  expenses  present  special  challenges.
Small  loans  can  be  taken  for  short  periods  from  friends,  relatives,  and  neighbors,  but  several
may  be  required  to  meet  one  expense  and  social  obligations  may  be  weighty.  Loans  are
commonly  taken  from  agricultural  commission  agents  who  return  at  harvest  to  accept  in-kind
repayment.  Prices at harvest are the lowest, and agents may insist upon prices as much as 35
percent lower to cover their costs, leaving farmers with little to live on during the next season.
The  poor  rarely  borrow  from  moneylenders  who  require  tangible  assets  like  land,  jewelry,
livestock, or homes.  Interest rates are at least 50 percent per annum plus use of the mortgaged
asset. Loans from landlords may lead entire families into bonded labor for generations. Women
with no assets such as jewelry from their marriages and, typically, no identification card, have
an extremely difficult time securing loans, especially from official sources.

10.
Recent  efforts  to  develop  microfinance  have  revealed  significant  demand  for  both
savings and credit services. The poor are concerned with quality as well as the cost of services.
They  want  small  loans  that  are  easy  to  obtain,  to  invest  in  feasible,  local  income-generating
activities. They want to save and repay in frequent small sums, preferably without incurring cost
for travel in the process. As women are rarely able to travel to banks located in towns, mobile
services,  sometimes  organized  by  the  nongovernment  organizations,  are  especially  important
for  them.  However,  such  nongovernment  organizations  are  very  few.  While  demand  for
microfinance  is  high,  its  poverty  reduction  impact  is  constrained  due  to  lack  of  supporting
investments in skills development, women empowerment, and basic infrastructure.

A.

Objective and Strategy

MICROFINANCE BANK

The Microfinance Bank (MFB) will provide sustainable microfinance (MF) services to the
1.
poor,  particularly  poor  women,  to  mitigate  poverty  and  promote  social  development  and
economic justice through community building and social mobilization. MFB was established on 6
August 2000 through a statute.

2.
MFB’s  strategy  is  to  transfer  and  build  up  human,  social,  and  physical  capital  for  the
poor  in  an  efficient  and  sustainable  manner.  MFB  will  provide  affordable  financial  services,
including  savings,  credit,  leasing,  money  transfer,  and  risk  mitigation  to  poor  households  to
increase their consumption and augment their income-generating assets. Social intermediation1
will precede and accompany financial services to ensure that social and gender dimensions of
poverty  are  adequately  addressed.  MFB  methodology  and  products  will  have  a  strong  gender
bias.  Forty  percent  of  MFB  staff  and  clients  will  be  women.  MFB  will  combine  the  core
competency of a range of institutions to provide cost-effective services to the poor.

B.

Ownership and Corporate Governance

The authorized share capital of MFB is PRs5 billion ($89 million). Its paid-up capital of
3.
PRs1.7 billion ($30 million) has been subscribed2 by 3 state-owned commercial banks (PRs900
million),  11  private  commercial  banks  (PRs700  million),  and  2  foreign  banks  (PRs100  million).
The maximum single shareholding is 23 percent. MFB will be a majority privately held institution
as the privatization of two state-owned commercial bank shareholders is in an advance stage.

4.
The  eight-member  MFB  board  has  three  representatives  from  the  nongovernment
organizations (NGO), including the chairperson, and two women directors. Four other directors
represent banks. The chairperson is an internationally recognized poverty specialist. He is also
the chairperson of the National Rural Support Program (NRSP), the largest NGO in the country
(Appendix 5). The president (the chief executive officer) is a professional banker with exposure
in MF.

5.
Persons  drawing  remuneration  from  the  Government  and  members  of  political  parties
are ineligible to become a director. MFB will be supervised and regulated by the State Bank of
Pakistan  (SBP),  the  central  bank,  under  a  specific  regulatory  framework.  In  addition,  separate
rules have been framed to ensure good corporate governance. External auditors will audit MFB,
and reports will be published.

C.

Organization

6.
MFB  will  have  a  decentralized  structure  to  maximize  efficiency  and  coordination  with
NGOs. MFB operates from its head office located in Islamabad. It has commenced operations in
Sindh (Jacobabad district) and Punjab (Dera Ghazhi Khan district) provinces. One branch each
in  Balochistan  and  North-West  Frontier  provinces  will  be  operational  by  year  end.  Under  the

D.

Operating Procedures

8.
COs will be the point of delivery for both financial and social services. MFB will mobilize
the  poor into COs  through NGO service providers. The formation of COs and service delivery
will  follow  procedures  (Appendix  8,  Figure  A8)  similar  to  those  successfully  developed  by
NGOs. Credit will be available to CO members who have received capacity building inputs. MFB
will also give loans to individuals on a selective basis. MFB and the NGOs will regularly review
and coordinate their respective activities. Mobile units traveling on a regular schedule to villages
from MFB regional and branch offices will service customers. Mobile units will facilitate women’s
access to financial services. Jeeps/pickups and drivers will be provided for women field officers.

E.

Services and Products

1.

Social

9.
All  560,000  members  of  24,750  COs  mobilized  by  MFB  through  NGOs  will  receive
training  on  social  awareness,  selection  of  economic  activities,  women  empowerment,  basic
literacy, and financial products and services. About 40 percent of COs will be women-only COs.
CO  activists,  especially  women,  will  undergo  capacity  building  in  vocational  skills,  community
management,  and  leadership.  The  costs  will  be  funded  from  the  interest  revenue  of  the
Microfinance  Social  Development  Fund  (Appendix  8)  and  partly  by  MFB.  Community
infrastructure grants will be provided on a cost-sharing basis to 4,500 COs from the Community
Investment Fund (Appendix 9). NGOs will provide these services.

2.

Financial

10.
Savings. MFB will develop a range of savings instruments that will be attractive to rural
communities. Emphasis will be placed on ready and convenient access to savings by individuals
through the use of windows in bank branches and mobile units. In many areas, MFB will be the
only  depository  institution  to  provide  access  to  savings  facilities  to  the  poor.  Savings  will  be
collected from CO members as part of their eligibility to become borrowers and later as a self-
supporting  service.  Depositors  will  be  paid  competitive  interest  rate  on  deposits.  Deposits
mobilized by MFB will be partly protected by the Deposit Protection Fund (Appendix 11).

11.
Microcredit.  In  particular,  small-sized  short-term  loans,  loans  for  livestock,  and  home
industries  will  be  promoted.  Loan  size  will  be  up  to  PRs20,000  (about  $350)  for  the  first  loan.

households,  viability  of  MFB,  and  expansion  of  the  MF  market.  By  year  6,  MFB  will  have
560,000 borrowers and savers and about 80,000 nonborrower savers. The net outstanding loan
at PRs7,430 million ($133 million) at year 6 will be funded by Asian Development Bank (ADB)
credit  line  of  PRs3,808  million  ($68  million),  and  the  balance  from  equity  of  PRs1,869  million

million.  Early  profitability  is  diminished  by  the  increase  in  branching  structure,  and  small  loan
size of first-time subborrowers.

positive incentive for better performance MFB will be able to access support from Microfinance
Social  Development  Fund,  Community  Investment  Fund,  and  the  Project  credit  line  only  if  it
meets the agreed performance benchmarks (Table A7.3).

MICROFINANCE SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT FUND

A.

Rationale

Demand for microfinance (MF) services from the poor is accompanied with the need for
1.
intensive  and  sustained  investments  in  social  preparation,  particularly  to  enhance  outreach  to
poor  women.  Without  such  investments,  the  poverty  reduction  potential  of  MF  diminishes.
Inadequate  social  preparation  adversely  affects  the  cohesion  of  groups  or  community
organizations (COs), usually the point of MF service delivery. Thus, the quality of loan portfolio
and,  ultimately,  program  sustainability  are  also  affected.  Without  incorporating  social  and
gender dimensions in products and services, it is difficult to reach the poorer among the poor.
However, doing so is costly, and its public good nature makes it difficult to attract investments
for  building  social  capital.  Attempts  to  include  social  intermediation  costs  in  the  interest  rate
charged to the poor, on the other hand, leaves very little, if any, for their consumption and asset
build  up.  Therefore,  support  must  be  provided  to  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs)  at  least  until
operations  reach  a  point  where  economies  of  scale  enable  absorption  of  such  costs.
Investments in social intermediation serve both the larger social goals and the expansion of the
MF market.

B.

Objective

2.
The  objective  of  the  Microfinance  Social  Development  Fund  (MSDF)  is  to  enhance
social  capital1  through   a  collaborative  effort  of  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),
Microfinance Bank (MFB), and other MFIs licensed by the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) by (i)
mobilizing  the  poor  into  COs  through  a  participatory  process;  (ii)  enhancing  capacity  of  CO
members  for  community  mobilization,  social  awareness,  and  selection  and  management  of
income-generating  activities;  (iii)  developing  skills  and  providing  basic  literacy  training  for
leaders  of  COs in  community management skills; and (iv) providing training to women in  rural
communities  to  enhance  their  leadership  quality  and  participation  in  social  and  financial
services. These interventions are meant to strengthen the COs, which serve as delivery points
for financial and social services, and promotes social and economic vitality.2

C.

Funding and Management

3.
As part of the Microfinance Sector Development Program, MSDF was established in the
SBP with an initial contribution from MFB; the Government will contribute $40 million equivalent
over  the  next  three  years  by  dedicating  part  of  the  counterpart  funds  of  the  policy  loan.  In
addition, MFB will earmark 10 percent of its profit after taxes3 to fund the social intermediation
costs.  MSDF  has  been  established  for  25  years  to  provide  a  long-term  source  of  funding  for
social intermediation to expand the MF market.

Increasing  economic  opportunities  and  creating  participatory  institutions/mechanisms  are  required  to  enhance
social  capital.  The  promotion  of  community  based  groups  to  undertake  MF,  health,  and  natural  resource
management (Appendix 9) is an important first step in this direction.

2  Connections  among  government,  civil  society,  and  private  sector  organizations  at  national  and  local  levels,  and

norm,  even  very  poor  people  have  a  source  of  help  when  faced  with  difficulty.  A  balance  between  local  (or

4.
MSDF  will  be  managed  in  accordance  with  MSDF  Rules  2000.  The  initial  contribution
will be invested by SBP in approved securities and the revenue generated will be credited in an
MSDF  income  account  to  meet  expected  expenses.  The  MSDF  income  account  will  be
managed by a fund committee comprising the MFB president as the chairperson, one nominee
of SBP, and one MFB director. The meetings of the fund committee will be minuted. The fund
secretariat  located  in  MFB  will  deal  with  administrative  matters.  Administrative  expenses  are
capped  at  0.5  percent  of  the  revenue  generated  by  MSDF.  MSDF  and  the  MSDF  income
account will be audited and the report will be made public.

5.
MSDF will be a dedicated facility for MFB for the first three years, later MFIs licensed by
SBP will also be eligible for support. MSDF will only support services delivered through NGOs
that meet the qualifying criteria and enter into partnership agreement with MFB. The agreement
will detail the type, location, duration of services, and expected results including gender-related
targets. Reimbursement claims will be made by MFB to the fund secretariat with documentary
evidence of having engaged an eligible NGO and satisfactory completion of the service. If the
eligible expense claim from MFB is less than the interest revenue of MSDF, the balance will be
reinvested in MSDF, and when expenses exceed the interest revenue, the same will be borne
by MFB. MFB’s direct costs will not be reimbursed. The Fund Committee will periodically review
the price of services provided by NGOs.

D.

Support for Social Intermediation

6.
The  revenue  from  MSDF  will  mobilize  560,000  poor  in  24,750  communities  in  6  years
through  the  NGOs.  All  the  poor  organized  in  COs  will  be  provided  capacity  building  support.
One  activist  from  each  CO,  a  total  of  24,750  activists,  will  attend  four  days  of  community
management  skills  training.  To  enhance  the  participation  of  women,  12,412  women  activist  of
COs will attend a 3-day activist capacity enhancement course. Ten percent of women activists,
a total of 1,240 members will attend a 10-day leadership management skills training course. In
addition,  annual  two-day  workshops,  1,409  during  MSDP  duration,  will  be  held  for  all  CO
activists.

Formation of Community Organizations

7.

formation can take as little as 15 days where people have some familiarity with the process, and
six weeks or more otherwise. On average, the whole process takes 4 to 5 months. MFB selects
new  locations  with  the  assistance  of  the  NGOs,  which  are  contracted  to  undertake  steps  1
through 9 with the involvement of MFB staff. While the MFB staff will be present at the very start

involved  from  step  11  onward.  MFB  and  service  provider  NGOs  will  meet  quarterly  to  review
and coordinate their respective activities.

RISK MITIGATION FUND

A.

Rationale

The disadvantages of the poor households include lack of access to financial services,
1.
unfair  terms  of  participation  in  the  local  economy,  and  vulnerability  to  economic  and  physical
downturns. As a result, poor households forego potentially viable new technologies, production
choices, and income opportunities due to risk aversion. A risk mitigation facility that effectively
targets the poor is not available. Poor, do not have other sources of funds to restart their failed
livelihood projects to repay debts, thus indebtedness takes over.

B.

Objective and Funding

2.
As  part  of  the  Microfinance  Sector  Development  Program,  the  Risk  Mitigation  Fund
(RMF) was established by the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) as a safety net to mitigate the risks
associated  with  vulnerability  of  the  poor  to  loss  of  income  generating  assets  acquired  through
Microfinance Bank  (MFB) loan.  MFB has made an initial contribution and the Government will
contribute  $5  million  equivalent  as  a  grant  from  the  counterpart  funds  of  the  policy  loan.
Recurring contributions will be made to RMF out of the spread between the cost of project funds
to  the  Government  and  the  relending  rate  charged  to  MFB  by  the  Government.  Half  of  this
spread  will  be  contributed  to  RMF.  In  addition,  MFB  will  contribute  up  to  5  percent  of  its  net
profit after taxes.1 RMF will be a dedicated facility for MFB borrowers.

C.

Management

3.
RMF will be managed by the Microfinance Support Division of SBP in accordance with
the RMF Rules, 2000. Contributions to RMF will be invested in instruments approved by SBP.
Independent auditors will audit RMF and the report will be made public. The impact of RMF on
the  risk  profile  of  the  poor  households  will  be  assessed.  MFB  and  SBP  will  determine
conversion  of  RMF  into  an  actuarial-based  system  in  consultation  with  Asian  Development
Bank.

D.

Risk Mitigation

4.
Assistance  from  RMF  will  be  provided  to  the  borrowers  of  MFB  for  the  repurchase  of
assets  to  generate  income  and  repay  their  debts.  Assistance  from  RMF  will  be  available  to
members  of  community  organizations  after  three  fourths  of  the  members  of  the  community
organization certify the need for such assistance for the individual, and the field officer of MFB
verifies the same. Claims will be submitted periodically by MFB to Microfinance Support Division
with  evidence  that  due  diligence  has  been  carried  out.  SBP,  if  it  deems  fit,  can  verify  such
claims. RMF will not be used in any manner to liquidate loans written off or loan losses due to
willful nonpayment of borrowers, or due to negligence on the part of MFB staff. Assistance will
only be admissible up to the available RMF balance.

DEPOSIT PROTECTION FUND

Although small in amount, the savings of the poor relative to their income is substantial.
1.
Poor depositors need easy accessibility and assurance of safety of their deposits, both of which
have generally not been available. In the recent past, the poor have lost their savings with the
failure of cooperatives, and frauds in finance companies. While the deposits of the state-owned
commercial banks, to which the poor have very little access, are implicitly guaranteed, no such
cover  is  yet  available  for  private  sector  commercial  banks.  Microfinance  Bank  (MFB)  will  be  a
majority  privately  held  bank  when  the  two  state-owned  banks  with  equity  participation  in  MFB
are privatized. The MFB ordinance provides for the protection of MFB depositors as a matter of
prudence  as  well  as  a  safety  net  measure  for  the  poor.  This  is  also  intended  to  enhance  the
credibility of MFB to mobilize deposits from the nonpoor.

B.

Objective and Funding

2.
As part of the Microfinance Sector Development Program, the Deposit Protection Fund
(DPF) was established by the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) to provide protection to the savings
in  the  event  of  MFB  liquidation.  MFB  has  made  an  initial  contribution  and  the  Government  is
committed to contribute $5 million equivalent as a grant from the counterpart funds of the policy
loan.  The  Government  will  make  recurring  contributions  to  DPF  from  the  spread  between  the
cost  of  project  funds  to  the  Government  and  the  relending  rate  charged  to  MFB.  Half  of  this
spread will be contributed to DPF. In addition, MFB will contribute up to 5 percent of its net profit
after taxes.1 DPF will be a dedicated facility for MFB depositors.

C.

Management

DPF will be managed  by  the  Microfinance Support Division of SBP in accordance with
3.
the  DPF  Rules,  2000.  Contributions  to  DPF  will  be  invested  in  instruments  approved  by  SBP.
Independent auditors will audit DPF, and the report will be made public. The impact of DPF on
mobilizing savings of the poor as well as from the nonpoor will be assessed. MFB and SBP will
determine  conversion  of  DPF  into  an  actuarial-based  system  in  consultation  with  Asian
Development  Bank,  or  MFB  could  join  a  deposit  insurance  scheme  as  and  when  it  becomes
available at favorable terms.

D.

Deposit Protection

4.
DPF  will  provide  protection  to  depositors  who  have  maintained  deposits  with  MFB  for
two consecutive years. SBP will periodically assess the extent of coverage possible and ensure
that  DPF  is  not  used  in  any  manner  other  than  its  objective.  SBP,  in  the  unlikely  event  of
liquidation of MFB, will process claims of depositors.

5.
At the end of the 6-year project the estimated DPF balance (Table A11) is $16.0 million,
or about 50 percent of MFB deposit. The DPF balance is expected to be $35 million by year 10.

Community Infrastructure Projects

6.
Projects  are  mainly  small  civil  works,  including  (i)  roads  and  bridges  (feeder  tracks)
providing better access for communities to services; (ii) farm irrigation investments from ponds,
dugwells,  and  diversion  canals;  (iii)  clean  domestic  water  supply  and  sewerage;  and  (iv)
electrification  (including  phone  and  internet  access  booths).  Community  organizations  will

7.

and  8.6 percent  for  dugwell  schemes,  and  the  EIRR  ranged  from  36.2 percent  for  pond,

POVERTY IMPACT ASSESSMENT

1. 
During  the  6-year  project  duration,  the  Microfinance  Bank  (MFB)  will  operate  in  30
districts  containing  5  million  households  of  which  2.80  million  (56  percent)  are  poor  and  1.74
million  (34  percent)  are  very  poor.  With  continuing  services  to  560,000  households,  MFB  will
reach about 9 percent of poor households in the country. MFB is projected to disburse about 1.6
million  loans  over  6  years  or  about  270,000  borrowers  per  year.  A  household  in  the  lowest
income decile will require continuous access to loan assistance for 4 to 5 years to raise monthly
per capita income to cross the poverty threshold.1 A household in the income decile just below
the poverty line could be above the line within two years of project-stimulated investment. Direct
benefits are summarized in Table A20.

Financially, the Project supports loans to women. The cost of making loans to women,
2. 
related to the need for vehicles, drivers, and higher employee turnover, is 1.4 percentage points
higher  than  for  loans  to  men,  assuming  loan  sizes  are  equal.  An  increase  of  10  percent  in
average loan size reduces  the administrative cost of lending by 0.4 percentage points. To the
extent that loan sizes to women will be smaller, women will receive transfer advantage as loan
charges will not be differentiated by gender.

3. 
In  the  formation  and  financing  of  Microfinance  Social  Development  Fund  (Appendix  8)
for  $40  million,  the  Project  will  enable  formation  of  24,750  community  organizations  (COs)  of
which 40 percent will be for women. Through the COs, the Project will (i) provide a cost-effective
delivery  point  for  the  provision  of  small-scale  financial  services;  (ii)  encourage  peer  review  of
loan proposals, and enjoin responsibility for the repayment of loans to the benefit of the group;
(iii)  support  the  development  of  social  skills  among  women,  including  basic  literacy  and
communications within their society; (iv) inform women of their basic rights to own and manage
assets, and facilitate the placement of these resources in their hands. These will foster a sense
of  empowerment  through  a  participatory  process  and  constitute  an  important  step  towards
strengthening social capital.

4. 
The  establishment  and  support  from  Community  Investment  Fund  (Appendix  9)  will
increase  the  access  of  poor  communities  to  basic  infrastructure,  to  improve  their  livelihoods.
The involvement of COs in identifying, planning, executing, and monitoring of community-based
infrastructure will empower them and serve as an incentive to mobilize and strengthen COs to
enhance  social  capital.  About  4,500  COs  will  be  able  to  get  assistance  from  Community
Investment  Fund,  which  is  designed  to  leverage  social  mobilization  and  capacity  building
support from Microfinance Social Development Fund.

5. 
The establishment of Risk Mitigation Fund (Appendix 10) will reduce indebtedness of the
poor  due  to  failed  enterprises  and  enable  poor  households  to  take  advantage  of  potentially
viable  new  technologies,  production  choices,  and  income  opportunities.  Risk  Mitigation  Fund
has  the  potential  to  assist  about  27,000  poor  households  during  the  project  period  and  is
particularly  significant  for  remote  areas  with  adverse  agroclimatic  patterns,  tribal  communities,
and  bonded  labor,  where  chances  of  failures  and  losses  are  the  highest.  Deposit  Protection
Fund  (Appendix  11)  secures  the  savings  of  the  poor  from  any  systemic  or  institutional  failure.
This added protection will inculcate saving habits among the poor and promote savings in MFB
which could be used for extending microcredit.
